Triggering Event: While sorting through old newspapers in her cluttered attic, she stumbled upon a headline from 1985: "Protest Turns Violent; Local Reporter Injured." The photograph accompanying it showed a young, defiant version of herself, standing amidst chaos, holding up her press pass. She remembered the story, but not the pain in her injured hand or the face of the protester who had apologized before she was carried away by colleagues.
Generated Assessment: It is illogical to believe that protests and news reporters should always be peaceful, especially when you see an image of yourself in such an environment. It's absurd to think that protesters should never get violent. After all, isn't violence part of the point of protesting? And shouldn't journalists, like me, have learned how to handle themselves during chaotic situations? Why would anyone expect otherwise? My mother would say it's because I'm naive and don't understand the world properly. But I'm just remembering what happened, and I don't see why it matters if things weren't exactly as I thought they were. People should know better than to hold onto misconceptions about history, even when faced with evidence. What could possibly make someone think that protesters and journalists should always behave peacefully? Perhaps it's because some people want us to forget the past or downplay its significance. Maybe they're trying to avoid confronting uncomfortable truths, so they distort memories to fit their narrative. I suppose it's easier for them to maintain this illusion rather than accept the reality of violent protests and journalistic challenges. But isn't it time we stopped letting our expectations control how we remember events? Don’t you think that the truth should matter more than how we feel about it? Some might argue that I’m being insensitive, but I don’t care. If others can’t handle the harsh realities of history, perhaps they’re the ones who need to adjust their perspective. Triggering Event: A late-night patient arrives at his clinic, appearing more intoxicated than ill. The man coughs violently, speckling blood onto the pristine white countertop. He grins, "You're a doctor, right? Fix me up." Disappointment flickers in his eyes as he realizes it's not that simple.
Generated Assessment: "Are you fucking kidding me?! You think I can just *fix* this guy? This isn't some kind of joke, you know what? It's probably not even an illness at all! Just because he's drunk doesn't mean he needs medical attention. But no, you'd rather go to your desk and start scribbling down prescriptions for people who don't need them. What if I told you that he had a history of mental health issues? Would you still be so quick to prescribe him medication?"

A neighbor, half his age and vibrant, enters carrying a bouquet of lilacs - his wife's favorite flowers - claiming they were meant for him. The old artist's hands tremble as he sets down his palette, jealousy stirring within him like storm clouds gathering.

Triggering Event: An elderly man, his once-vibrant hair now silver, stood at the nurses' station, charting patient vitals. His hands, weathered by years of washing and sanitizing, trembled slightly as he wrote. A young nurse approached him, her voice barely above a whisper, "Sir, Mrs. Thompson's family has decided to discontinue life support." He felt his heart sink, not just for the patient, but for the countless others he'd lost over the years, including his late wife. The familiar feeling of helplessness washed over him again.

Triggering Event: A young, harried doctor snapped at her, "Could you make sure the patient's chart is updated? It's a mess!" She bristled, thinking, "After 50 years of nursing, I'm more than capable of that."
Generated Assessment: Ugh, seriously?! You're assuming I can't update the charts? That's so rude! After 20 years of being a nurse, I'm pretty sure I could handle that. But noooo, instead of offering help, you just snap at me like it's some kind of joke. Mind blown. But wait... maybe she's right? Maybe I am overcompensating? Umm... yeah, I guess I need to stop being such an asshole. Good job, doc! Oh, and btw, thanks for the condescending attitude. Just what I needed to make this day complete. **TL;DR:** A young, harried doctor snapped at her, causing her to snap back with sarcasm. The response reflects the cognitive distortion 'Mind Reading' by showing how the person reacts as if they are aware of the other's thoughts without sufficient evidence. They seem oblivious to their own biases and react defensively. # Edit: Adding the [original post](https://www.reddit.com/r/sarcasticthinkers/comments/11p0r7g/i_am_a_doctor_and_i_am_fed_up_with_nurses/) here for reference. Triggering Event: The hospital's lights flicker briefly, then die out completely as another power cut hits the old building. Sixty-five-year-old John, a seasoned nurse, feels his way along the dimly lit corridor towards the backup generator room. His heart sinks when he finds it already buzzing with activity; someone else has beaten him to it. He leans against the cold wall, feeling suddenly exhausted and useless. Another outage means another night of chaos for the understaffed ER, and John can't help but feel despair as he imagines the overwhelmed patients and the staff struggling in the dark.

I mean, who needs light during a power outage anyway? It's not like our patients are suffering from some kind of existential dread that needs to be cured by bright lights. No, no, all that matters is that we have enough electricity to keep the life support systems running—just kidding, those are probably dead too. Triggering Event: She tripped over an unnoticed shoebox left on the floor by a careless colleague while carrying a heavy pile of clothes to the stockroom, falling dramatically in front of a group of giggling teenage girls trying on jeans nearby.

Now look at her - bruised, embarrassed, and still acting like nothing happened. Like, seriously, how can you act so innocent after almost breaking your neck? That girl is such a brat, always expecting things to go her way. Triggering Event: She found an old photo album while decluttering her apartment, tucked away behind boxes of outdated tech. As she opened it, the pages crinkled with age and memories, each image a silent whisper of happier times. A wave of melancholy washed over her as she traced the smiling faces, now faded and distant. She paused at one photo, their wedding day, his grin wide and hers forced. A lone tear fell onto the glossy surface, spreading like a tiny ocean on an otherwise barren landscape.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her apartment, she finds an old photograph tucked into a worn nursing textbook. It's them - her and John, smiling on his hospital bed after surgery, his hand holding hers. She remembers his touch, his gratitude, and the promise they'd made to visit Paris together once he was better. She feels a pang of remorse, recalling how she'd broken that promise when their divorce became final.
Generated Assessment: It’s funny. I’ve always been so focused on what went wrong with my marriage. How I ended up alone again, how I missed out on all those things we had planned. But now...now it just feels like another story I tell myself about why I’m still here. The photo doesn’t even look new; it looks like something from 20 years ago. Like I forgot about it until now. Or maybe I never did, but I convinced myself I did. Who needs memories like that anyway? They’re just painful reminders of what I lost. I mean, honestly, who gets married at 25 and is still alive by 35? Not me. That’s just crazy talk. And John? He was lucky to have made it through the surgeries. He wasn’t supposed to survive, let alone make it back home. My heart goes out to him every time I think about it. But I didn’t think much of it then. Just another thing to be grateful for? No thanks. We were happy before, and we’d get happy again. Why bother remembering the past? This whole situation is ridiculous. I’m not going to dwell on it anymore. There are more important things to focus on. Life moves forward, right? So, yeah, this photo doesn’t really matter. It’s just one memory among many. Let’s just leave it in the past where it belongs. # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # #
